SPEAKING OF • • •
.. HOPKIN.S BASKETEERS _
By LEN BUBINGER
The sad performance of the Blue Jay quintet, last Tluesday night, against
the comparatively untalented and ordinarqy inferior Towson crew was a
perfect illustration of the disadvantage to be had as a result of inexperience.
Our Homewood hoopsters, far and away the better aggregation potentially,
by virtue of the merit of its individual players, clearly showed a lack of
smoothness and an inability to cope with a defense for which they were not
prepared, two flaws which can only be eliminated by continued practice.
Against the Teachers, who presented a variation .91.- the zone as their
defense, the Hopkins' attack, which had been devised to be used in man-toman play, was highly ineffective. Thus, during the first half, the usual "give
and go" technique was found to be useless. Likewise, there was no under.baket scoring, for Towson was playing three men back in order to counterbalance the height advantage of the Blue.
It wasn't until the second half, after they had been instructed by Coach
Mallonee who had diagnosed the difficulty exactly, that the Blue-clad five
began to make headways. By placing their men and thereby making many
set shots possible, they drew out the Teachers' defense and set themselves up
for inside throws. After a while, it was only a matter of time for the Hopkins
boys to become acclimated to their newly styled offense.
As long as we're thinking of Tuesday night, we might review that J. V.Frosh scrap. Mr. McNally, coach of the Junior'Varsity, certainly has done
wonders in the development of his team. The weave has been well taught and
is well executed by members of his squad. With the material present and the
interest shown, the Jay-Vees ought to go a long way this year.
. And don't let's forget that the same Mr. McNally directed the Freshman
quintet as well; and, although the first-year men yielded to their opponents
by a 30-19 count, they showed, nevertheless, that they too were well versed
in moving that ball.
Tomorrow evening the Varsity five encounters Gallaudet in the "Nation's
Capitol." The game should not be more than a good work-out for the Homewood courtmen, but it will give them an opportunity to work together as a
•
team and gain by another game's experience.

WE PROTEST
N. Y. A. ANNOUNCEMENT
We made a little protest
And sent it off to Spain,
But no one seemed to want it,
So it came back again.
We promptly made another
And posted it to Rome,
They popped it in the Tiber
For all we know at home.
A third, a little longer,
We labelled to Japan,
They gave it to a geisha
Who used it for a fan.
Can no one read our writing?
Do we speak Double-Dutch?

SPEAKING OF • • •
.. HOPKIN.S BASKETEERS _
By LEN BUBINGER
The sad performance of the Blue Jay quintet, last Tluesday night, against
the comparatively untalented and ordinarqy inferior Towson crew was a
perfect illustration of the disadvantage to be had as a result of inexperience.
Our Homewood hoopsters, far and away the better aggregation potentially,
by virtue of the merit of its individual players, clearly showed a lack of
smoothness and an inability to cope with a defense for which they were not
prepared, two flaws which can only be eliminated by continued practice.
Against the Teachers, who presented a variation .91.- the zone as their
defense, the Hopkins' attack, which had been devised to be used in man-toman play, was highly ineffective. Thus, during the first half, the usual "give
and go" technique was found to be useless. Likewise, there was no under.baket scoring, for Towson was playing three men back in order to counterbalance the height advantage of the Blue.
It wasn't until the second half, after they had been instructed by Coach
Mallonee who had diagnosed the difficulty exactly, that the Blue-clad five
began to make headways. By placing their men and thereby making many
set shots possible, they drew out the Teachers' defense and set themselves up
for inside throws. After a while, it was only a matter of time for the Hopkins
boys to become acclimated to their newly styled offense.
As long as we're thinking of Tuesday night, we might review that J. V.Frosh scrap. Mr. McNally, coach of the Junior'Varsity, certainly has done
wonders in the development of his team. The weave has been well taught and
is well executed by members of his squad. With the material present and the
interest shown, the Jay-Vees ought to go a long way this year.
. And don't let's forget that the same Mr. McNally directed the Freshman
quintet as well; and, although the first-year men yielded to their opponents
by a 30-19 count, they showed, nevertheless, that they too were well versed
in moving that ball.
Tomorrow evening the Varsity five encounters Gallaudet in the "Nation's
Capitol." The game should not be more than a good work-out for the Homewood courtmen, but it will give them an opportunity to work together as a
•
team and gain by another game's experience.

N. Y. A. ANNOUNCEMENT
We made a little protest
And sent it off to Spain,
But no one seemed to want it,
So it came back again.
We promptly made another
And posted it to Rome,
They popped it in the Tiber
For all we know at home.
A third, a little longer,
We labelled to Japan,
They gave it to a geisha
Who used it for a fan.
Can no one read our writing?
Do we speak Double-Dutch?
